bibl.title: Letter from Harold C. Ernst to Howard A. Kelly, November 27, 1908

div1.p: Ernst seeks Kelly's advice in order to organize a campaign in support of Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Harold C. Ernst to Howard A. Kelly, November 27, 1908
div1.opener:
ans 12/7/08
Harvard University Medical School
THE DEPARTMENT OF BACTERIOLOGY
240 LONGWOOD AVENUE,
BOSTON.
November 27, 1908.
My dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
I have received the documents enclosed to me under date of November twenty-
fifth referring to the Kissinger matter, and I have also received your book
upon Walter Reed, which I shall value very highly.

I understood in a letter from Dr. Welch that he left the matter to you and
to me, and that he would agree to take any action that we settled upon. Have
you any suggestions to make? Would another appeal to the Carnegie people backed
by Welch, yourself and me as the President of the Association of Pathologists
and Bacteriologists, or by a larger committee, have any influence? Do you think
this should be done at once, or do you think that an appeal to the general pub-
lic in the newspapers of the country, or to the medical profession through the
medical journals, would be the proper course, or do you think that the two had
best be combined?

In case you approve of a general appeal, would you allow your name to be
used, together with that of Dr. Welch and mine? Will you suggest any other names
to be added for such a committee, for example, perhaps Hektoen or Billings of
Chicago, or both; Vaughan, Novy or Warthin of Ann Arbor; possibly Adami of
Montreal; Prudden, Flexner or Ewing of New York. Perhaps it would be well to
put in a number of clinicians, and if you think it best to carry out that sug-
gestion, I should be glad if you would give me the names of some of those that
you think should be included. Personally I feel that a small committee is
likely to have as much influence as a larger one, and, at any rate, that its
working capacity will be better.

If you consent, I shall be entirely willing to constitute myself the cor-
responding force in the matter, and would see that some sort of an appeal should
be sent to a number of medical journals, and to a number of influential papers
in different parts of the country. Of course a treasurer should be selected,
and for that purpose I feel justified in offering the services of Mr. F. L.
Higginson, a banker of this city. I merely make that suggestion because I
know him quite well personally, and am confident that he would serve.

It seems to me from the condition of the man whatever is done should be
done quickly, and I take it that Dr. Dean of South Bend knows the individual
well enough to be called upon for information.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Harold C. Ernst. Dr. Howard A. Kelly.
